16.text:
You’ve got to ask the right questions. Loads
of the numbers that I used came from Government

21.text:
but I only got those numbers because I asked
Parliamentary Questions day in, day out. Sometimes

27.text:
I didn’t get the answers that I wanted or
needed, but sometimes I got a little gem that

33.text:
you could use to make a story in a newspaper
and to keep the argument going.

38.text:
The second leads onto the issue of news angles.
You’ve got to make this as uncomfortable

43.text:
as possible for the government. If this is
a one day story – a headline in one paper

47.text:
on one day – that quickly goes away and
it doesn’t really matter. You’ve got to

52.text:
keep this going day after day, week after
week, until you get the result you want. We

56.text:
did that with the state pension age, it’s
happening with the tax on multinational companies

61.text:
and it happened with tax credits even though
we only got a partial victory on all of these.

65.text:
You’ve got to make it uncomfortable and
you’ve got to keep the story going. There’s

69.text:
lots of ways you can do that. I’ve given
the example already of making sure that the

72.text:
numbers work but you’ve also got to make
sure that you’re bringing people into the

76.text:
campaign. If the campaign is just a campaign
in Parliament it won’t succeed. You’ve

81.text:
got to bring people in from the outside. So,
for example, can you work with an outside

86.text:
organisation to get a petition going? Get
a petition going on the Number 10 website,

91.text:
to get a 38 Degrees petition, to get a business
or a trade union to launch a petition? Can

99.text:
you get organisations to come out and oppose
something the Government’s doing? Can the

105.text:
Child Poverty Action Group say something?
Can the CBI back up your case? Can you find

114.text:
respected external people? One of our big
successes again on the state pension age campaign

118.text:
is that SAGA, which sends its magazine to
so many people, ran stories on this. We did

126.text:
it in women’s magazines as well.
So can you get that story out there by having

131.text:
other credible people backing it up and having
case studies? Those sorts of things are so

136.text:
important and with campaigns like tax credits
and the state pension age it’s easy to find

140.text:
people who are effected by the changes to
make that case for you because all the numbers

145.text:
in the world are not as good as a real life
story of somebody effected.

152.text:
The third thing that I think makes a successful
campaign is using all of the devices that

159.text:
you have in parliament, and there are a lot
of them. So you can use Prime Minister’s

164.text:
Questions, you can use Treasury Questions.
Those kinds of things get on the telly and

168.text:
they get on the radio. You can use Opposition
Day Debates. The Opposition is allotted a

174.text:
certain number of days in Parliament where
we can decide what the business in Parliament

179.text:
is rather than the Government deciding. Every
day you can submit to have an Urgent Question

184.text:
in Parliament on something that has become
topical over the last 24 hours. You can use

191.text:
that as a chance to raise issues of concern.
You can use Westminster Hall debates or adjournment

197.text:
debates. You can use evidence at select committees;
not just to make your point, but to influence

203.text:
who’s coming in to give evidence so you’ve
got the person who you want to hold to account

208.text:
or the person you think can provide ammunition
for your campaign.

220.text:
The first and most obvious way in which a
committee report might influence the Government

225.text:
is if specific action is taken as a result
of the recommendations.

231.text:
The Committee did a report on the audit market
and whether the limited number of accountancy

238.text:
firms was preventing competition and hindering
that market. The crucial recommendation in

245.text:
the Committee’s report was there should
be a review by the Competition Commission.

249.text:
That was taken up, there was a review and
the review recommended and reflected a number

256.text:
of issues raised by the Committee. So there
is a direct action as a result of that report.

265.text:
The second way the Committee can influence
Government is through influencing the immediate

270.text:
debate in the House of Lords and possibly
the House of Commons. This happened with the

276.text:
Committee’s report in financial devolution
to Scotland. You probably remember at the

284.text:
closing days of the Scottish Referendum a
vow was made to the Scottish people that further

290.text:
devolution of powers to them would follow
if independence was rejected. That devolution

299.text:
is the Scotland Bill, which is currently going
through Parliament. It is also in something

304.text:
entitled the ‘Fiscal Framework’, which
is, I assure you, more exciting than it sounds.

310.text:
It is essentially the agreement between the
governments about the mechanics of how financial

314.text:
devolution will work. This document is crucially
important and at the time the Committee reported

322.text:
and the time the House of Lords and House
of Commons were considering the Scotland Bill

328.text:
was not available. It had not been agreed
between the two governments. The Economic

334.text:
Affairs Committee were among the first to
draw attention to this, in very strident language.

345.text:
If being on breakfast TV is a mark of success,
it lead the Scottish breakfast TV stories

350.text:
for the best part of two days, that committee
report, and resulted in the Government re-timetabling

356.text:
the Scotland Bill in the Lords to allow the
Fiscal Framework to be published before the

361.text:
Bill finished its passage through the House.
The next way the Committee can influence the

372.text:
Government is through what the Institute for
Government rather patronisingly, I think,

378.text:
calls ‘pester power’, which is about following
up and being persistent on an issue. This

387.text:
has been seen in HS2. Although the report’s
central recommendation, which was that there

396.text:
wasn’t an economic case for HS2, has not
been taken up by the Government—HS2 is still

401.text:
ongoing—the Committee has been continually
writing to the Government, challenging the

407.text:
figures coming out, challenging the responses,
which has resulted in information coming into

413.text:
the public domain which otherwise would not
have done so.

419.text:
And lastly there is influencing the longer
term debate. If a committee has done a very

428.text:
thorough analysis of a tricky issue over a
lengthy period that is sometimes used and

435.text:
taken in long term policy discussions. The
Committee’s report on immigration is something

442.text:
that is still cited, although it is not a
particularly new report now, in analysis of
